title: Bellatrix (band)
text:
Bellatrix were an <a href="Iceland">Iceland</a>ic <a href="rock%20group">rock group</a>. The group was founded in 1992 in <a href="Keflav%C3%ADk">Keflavík</a> as Kolrassa krókríðandi (Black-ass Hookrider) by four women, all aged sixteen: Elíza M Geirsdóttir (<a href="vocals">vocals</a> and <a href="violin">violin</a>), Sigrún Eiríksdóttir (<a href="guitar">guitar</a>), Ester Bíbí Ásgeirsdóttir (<a href="bass%20guitar">bass</a>) and Birgitta Vilbersdóttir (<a href="drum">drum</a>s).
History.
The band released the mini-album "Drápa" (named after the form of <a href="Skald">skaldic poetry</a>) in 1992. In 1994, they released "Kynjasögur" ("Family Stories") with Anna Margrét Hraundal (<a href="guitar">guitar</a>) and Karl Ágúst Guðmundsson (<a href="trumpet">trumpet</a> and <a href="Electronic%20keyboard">keyboard</a>) replacing Birgitta. Two years later, in 1996, they released "Köld eru kvennaráð" ("Cold are the counsels of women," likely referencing a famous line from <a href="Nj%C3%A1ls%20saga">Njáls saga</a>).
They also released "Stranger Tales" in 1995, which featured some <a href="English%20language">English</a> versions of <a href="Icelandic%20language">Icelandic</a> songs. This was also their first <a href="Compact%20disc">CD</a> published under the name Bellatrix. This was followed by "G" in 1998 released on Global Warming Records. In 1999, they moved to London and signed to <a href="Fierce%20Panda">Fierce Panda</a>. They headlined a mini <a href="United%20Kingdom">UK</a> <a href="concert%20tour">tour</a> in the autumn of 1999, with <a href="Coldplay">Coldplay</a> joining them as co-headliner. The following year, they released "It's All True" with Fierce Panda. Their <a href="Single%20%28music%29">single</a>, "Jedi Wannabe", peaked at #65 in the <a href="UK%20Singles%20Chart">UK Singles Chart</a> in September 2000. They broke up the following year, with most of the band returning to Iceland except Elíza, who remained in London to continue studying music.
